validation_metadata.verification_method: Complete manual review of Va. Code § 2.2-3700 et seq.

rights_of_access.description: All public records and meetings shall be presumed open unless an exemption is properly invoked. Government affairs are not intended to be conducted in secrecy. The public is to be the beneficiary of any government action.
rights_of_access.conditions: Exemption must be specifically invoked pursuant to VFOIA or other specific law
rights_of_access.applies_to: All persons seeking Virginia public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This presumption is foundational - agencies must overcome it to withhold records, not requesters to obtain them
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3700 presumes all records are open. You bear the burden of properly invoking a specific exemption.'

rights_of_access.description: VFOIA must be liberally construed to promote increased awareness of governmental activities and afford every opportunity to witness government operations. Exemptions shall be narrowly construed. When ambiguous, resolve in favor of access.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to all VFOIA interpretation; exemptions narrowly construed
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts must interpret doubts in favor of disclosure - agencies cannot construe exemptions broadly
rights_of_access.request_tips: Argue: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3700 mandates liberal construction favoring access. This exemption claim must be narrowly construed and cannot defeat the general policy of disclosure.'

rights_of_access.description: Any local ordinance that conflicts with VFOIA provisions is void. State FOIA rights cannot be diminished by local rules or restrictions.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to all local government ordinances conflicting with VFOIA
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Local governments cannot create more restrictive rules than state law - state standards prevail
rights_of_access.request_tips: If local restriction cited: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3700 voids local ordinances conflicting with VFOIA. Please process under state law standards.'

rights_of_access.description: Every person has the right to inspect and copy public records. These are separate rights - inspection can occur without copying, allowing record review without duplication fees.
rights_of_access.conditions: Subject to statutory exemptions; reasonable times and circumstances
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Inspection is typically free; copying involves fees. Inspect first to determine what to copy.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Under Va. Code § 2.2-3704, I request to inspect [records] without making copies at this time.'

rights_of_access.description: Public bodies must respond within 5 working days of receipt. Day one is the day after request received. Weekends and holidays excluded. Requests after 5:00 PM count as next working day.
rights_of_access.conditions: 5 working days from receipt; substantive response required
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: One of the faster state deadlines. Response must state whether providing records, denying, or taking extension.
rights_of_access.request_tips: After 5 days: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3704 requires response within 5 working days. Today is day [X]. Please respond immediately.'

rights_of_access.description: If impossible to respond in 5 days, agency may take 7 additional working days (12 total) but must notify in writing within initial 5 days, explain conditions making response impossible, and state when records will be provided.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must notify within 5 days; must explain impossibility; must specify production date; 12-day total maximum
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agency must prove impossibility, not mere inconvenience. Generic 'we're busy' is insufficient.
rights_of_access.request_tips: If extended: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3704 requires explanation of specific conditions making 5-day response impossible. Please provide detailed justification and exact production date within 12-day maximum.'

rights_of_access.description: Requests received after 5:00 PM are considered received the next working day. Day one is the day after receipt. This provides clear calculation rules preventing timing disputes.
rights_of_access.conditions: After 5 PM = next working day; day one = day after receipt
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Submit time-sensitive requests before 5 PM and request receipt acknowledgment
rights_of_access.request_tips: State: 'Submitted at [time] on [date]. Under Va. Code § 2.2-3704, day one is [date]. Your response is due by [5 working days later].'

rights_of_access.description: Fees limited to actual costs of responding: staff search time, copying costs, directly related expenses. Cannot charge general overhead or administrative costs.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be actual costs; must be directly related; no overhead
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Challenge any overhead, facility costs, or padded search time estimates
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3704 prohibits general overhead charges. Provide itemized breakdown showing only actual direct costs: search time (actual hours), copying, directly related expenses.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies may require deposit only if estimated costs exceed $200. Must provide written estimate before requiring deposit. This protects from surprise deposit demands.
rights_of_access.conditions: Only if costs exceed $200; written estimate required first
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Request written estimate, review carefully, negotiate scope if costs excessive
rights_of_access.request_tips: If deposit demanded: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3704 requires written estimate before deposit. Provide itemized estimate. I may modify request if costs excessive.'

rights_of_access.description: No specific form required for requests. May be oral or written. Must adequately identify records and submit to custodian.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must adequately identify records; must submit to proper custodian
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Written recommended for documentation but not required
rights_of_access.request_tips: If form demanded: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3704 requires no specific format. This [oral/written/email] request is acceptable.'

rights_of_access.description: Public bodies must make reasonable efforts to reach agreement with requester on production and format. This includes allowing request modifications to reduce costs or clarify scope.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency must engage in good faith; modifications must be reasonable
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Use this to negotiate scope, format, or delivery method when costs are high
rights_of_access.request_tips: Propose: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3704 requires reasonable efforts to reach agreement. I propose [modification] to facilitate production.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must provide records in format requested if readily available in that format. Cannot force requesters to accept different format if requested format exists.
rights_of_access.conditions: Format must be readily available; not required to create new formats
rights_of_access.applies_to: Electronic records maintained in requested format
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: If agency has Excel files, can request Excel. If database format exists, can request that.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Specify: 'These records are maintained in [format]. Va. Code § 2.2-3704 requires provision in requested format if readily available. Provide in [native format].'

rights_of_access.description: Electronic records have same status as physical records. Includes metadata, system logs, databases. Agencies cannot deny based on electronic format.
rights_of_access.conditions: Format considerations required; metadata included
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Request metadata explicitly - creation dates, authors, edit history all part of electronic record
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3704 grants electronic records same status as physical. Provide [records] in electronic format with all associated metadata.'

rights_of_access.description: Any person denied VFOIA rights may petition court for mandamus or injunction. Must be supported by affidavit showing good cause. Direct judicial access without administrative appeals.
rights_of_access.conditions: Affidavit with good cause required; proper venue; filing in general district or circuit court
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: No administrative exhaustion required - go straight to court
rights_of_access.request_tips: If denied: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3713 authorizes mandamus/injunction. I will petition [proper court] if access not provided.'

rights_of_access.description: VFOIA petitions must be heard within 7 days of filing. Opposing party gets copy at least 3 working days prior. Fastest FOIA judicial process in the nation.
rights_of_access.conditions: Hearing within 7 days; 3-day notice to opposing party; court must prioritize
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This expedited process ensures fast resolution - faster than nearly any other state
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3713 requires hearing within 7 days. Schedule no later than [7 days from filing].'

rights_of_access.description: Substantially prevailing petitioners entitled to recover reasonable costs, expert fees, and attorney fees unless special circumstances make award unjust. Fee recovery is presumptive, not discretionary.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must substantially prevail; fees must be reasonable; agency bears burden to show special circumstances
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Special circumstances are rare - agency must prove, not just assert, that fee award would be unjust
rights_of_access.request_tips: In petition: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3713 entitles me to attorney fees if I substantially prevail. Respondent bears burden to show special circumstances.'

rights_of_access.description: Knowing and willful VFOIA violations subject public body to civil penalty: $500-$2,000 first offense, up to $2,000 subsequent offenses. Separate from attorney fees.
rights_of_access.conditions: Violation must be knowing and willful; court determines amount
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Knowing and willful means deliberate, not negligent. Pattern of violations or ignoring clear law supports finding.
rights_of_access.request_tips: If willful violation: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3714 imposes civil penalties for knowing and willful violations. Request penalties in addition to other relief.'

rights_of_access.description: Virginia Freedom of Information Advisory Council provides guidance, training, advisory opinions, and maintains FOIA officer directory. Resource available to requesters for complex FOIA questions.
rights_of_access.conditions: Located in legislative branch; opinions advisory not binding but persuasive
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Advisory Council opinions are highly persuasive and frequently cited by courts
rights_of_access.request_tips: Reference: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3704.1 establishes FOIA Advisory Council for guidance. I consulted [or will consult] Council regarding this matter.'

rights_of_access.description: Public bodies should designate FOIA officer as contact point. Names maintained on Advisory Council website. Creates accountability and clear contact.
rights_of_access.conditions: Designation recommended; officer serves as request contact
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Most agencies comply. Direct requests to designated FOIA officer for proper routing.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Address to: 'FOIA Officer designated per Va. Code § 2.2-3704.1. If not appropriate officer, forward immediately and notify me.'

rights_of_access.description: No record shall be withheld unless specifically made exempt pursuant to VFOIA or other specific law. Exemptions cannot be construed broadly to defeat access policy.
rights_of_access.conditions: Exemption must be specific; cannot be generic or implied
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Generic sensitivity or confidentiality claims insufficient - must cite specific statutory exemption
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge: 'Va. Code § 2.2-3700 requires specific exemption authority. Cite exact statute authorizing withholding, not general confidentiality claims.'
